overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #95 from erdosproblems.com. Originally offered with a prize of $500.
overview.problemStatement:
Forum
Favourites

Let $x_1,\ldots,x_n\in\mathbb{R}^2$ determine the set of distances $\{u_1,\ldots,u_t\}$. Suppose $u_i$ appears as the distance between $f(u_i)$ many pairs of points. Then for all $\epsilon>0$\[\sum_i f(u_i)^2 \ll_\epsilon n^{3+\epsilon}.\]



The case when the points determine a convex polygon was solved by Fishburn \cite{Al63}. Note it is trivial that $\sum f(u_i)=\binom{n}{2}$. Solved by Guth and Katz \cite{GuKa15} who proved the upper bound\[ \sum_i f(u_i)^2 \ll n^3\log n.\]See also [94].




References


[Al63] Altman, E., On a problem of P. Erd\H{o}s. Amer. Math. Monthly (1963), 148-157.

[GuKa15] Guth, Larry and Katz, Nets Hawk, On the Erd\H{o}s distinct distances problem in the plane. Ann. of Math. (2) (2015), 155-190.
